contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=June 2011}} [[Image:Rape Marpessa Staatliche Antikensammlungen 2417 n2.jpg|thumb|right|280px|Marpessa and [[Idas]], separated of [[Apollo]] by [[Zeus]], [[Attica|Attic]] red-figure [[psykter]], ca. 480 BC, [[Staatliche Antikensammlungen]] (Inv. 2417).]] In [[Greek mythology]], '''Marpessa''' ({{lang-grc|Μάρπησσα|Márpessa}}, ‘the robbed one’) was an [[Aetolia]]n princess, and a granddaughter of [[Ares]]. According to another myth, she was the daughter of [[Evenus (mythology)|Evenus]] and [[Alcippe (Greek mythology)|Alcippe]]. She loved [[Idas]] and was loved by him in return. She was also loved by the god [[Apollo (god)|Apollo]]. When Idas asked to marry Marpessa, Evenus refused his request. Idas went to [[Poseidon]] and begged for the use of a winged [[chariot]].<ref>[[Jeanie Lang]]. ''A Book of Myths'', p. 90-99.</ref> Poseidon consented to his use of the chariot, and Idas stole Marpessa away and fled. Her father, after chasing the couple for a long time and realizing he could not catch up to them, killed his horses and then drowned himself in a nearby river, which took his name. Apollo also pursued them in his own chariot, wanting Marpessa for himself. Eventually [[Zeus]] intervened and commanded Marpessa to choose between her mortal lover and the god.<ref>[[Jeanie Lang]]. ''A Book of Myths'', p. 90-99.</ref> Marpessa chose Idas, reasoning to Apollo that had she chosen the god, she would have eventually grown old and lost his affections: :"And thou beautiful god, in that far time, :When in thy setting sweet thou gazest down :On this grey head, wilt thou remember then :That once I pleased thee, that I once was young?"<ref>[[Stephen Phillips]]. ''Marpessa (poem)''.</ref> Marpessa is also the name of an [[Amazons|Amazon]] Queen. == Ancient references == [[File:Idas and Marpessa, A Book of Myths.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Illustration of Marpessa by Helen Stratton from Jeanie Lang's 1915 ''A Book of Myths''.]] Marpessa and her story are quoted in several ancient sources, among them: *[[Homer]], ''[[Iliad]]'' 9.556; 8th century B.C.; *[[Propertius]], ''Elegies'' 1.2; 1st century B.C.; *[[Plutarch]], ''[[Parallel Lives]]'' 40; 1st-2nd century A.D.; *Pseudo-Appollodorus, ''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Library]]'' 1.7.8-9, 1.60; 2nd century A.D. == Modern use of the name == It is thought that the modern and rare Italian female personal name [[Marfisa]] and the variants Marfisia and Marfisio (male version) descend from Marpessa.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} This is probably supported by the history of the evolution of the name itself.{{citation needed|date=September 2012}} ''Marpessa'', as a name, was used to describe a 206,000 ton [[Shell Oil]] company [[supertanker]] ([[VLCC]]). In December 1969, it became the world's largest oil tanker to sink up to that date. Marpessa had been on its maiden voyage from [[Europoort|Europort]], [[Rotterdam]], when an explosion ripped through the hull and it foundered 50 miles off the west coast of [[Africa]]. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{fr icon}} [http://grenier2clio.free.fr/grec/amazone.htm Amazones] [[Category:Aetolian mythology]] [[Category:Offspring of Ares]] [[Category:Apollo]] {{Greek-myth-stub}}
